What!? We’ve been doing major work on climate for two centuries now. Coincidentally, the unscientific but usually reliable at long-range weather forecasting Farmers' Almanac started 202 years ago as well. And why wouldn’t we be doing the research? When it comes to the realities of life on Earth, climate stands as one of the constant and concerning realities of life here, affecting everything from crop timing and crop yields to wedding planning. We would have been better off had politicians decided to ignore Al Gore’s version of climate change. The parameters put on the enormous flow of funding to research Catastrophic Anthropogenic Global Warming all but assured the results would be an indictment of industrialism. But, at least, it was in the form of an actual scientific claim. Never mind that the claim was that science up to that point had been wrong in important respects, we proceeded to give it a lot of actual investigation (not to mention a lot of meetings of lots of important people at resort spots all around the world). You may recall that that claim fell apart in 2004 in a rapid-fire exchange of “oh shit, oh shit” emails flying between climate centers as the predicted rise in temperature not only failed to materialize to the predicted degree, it failed to materialize to any degree. Of 42 predictive models, all were wrong. Consequently, we haven’t seen predictive models or hypotheses or any other real scientific claim since then. We’re being treated to a PR regalia. CAGW became AGW became “global warming” became “climate change,” growing more and more diffuse as it became about globalist politics and not science. One of the reasons climate is concerning is that we are in not one but two ice ages. Both poles are ice covered. The Pleistocene ice age started ~27 mya when the South American plate separated from the Antarctic plate, and the Quaternary ice age started 2.58 mya in the northern hemisphere. We will be in these ice ages for millions of years to come. Hello, Al! An ice age is a great time to be figuring out how to get some warming, not fret about it. Those pre-ice-age epochs of our Cenozoic era that were 4 and 6 degrees C warmer than now, were much nicer! …worldwide Mediterranean climates. Interglacials, like our present Holocene, instead feature notoriously fickle and shitty weather. This interglacial will end before long, perhaps with this solar minimum, perhaps with the one that follows.
